lines: MR ZELJKO GRGUREV
PRESIDENT:  Mr Grgurev, before I invite Mr Catchpole to ask
further questions, I just remind you that the oath which
you took {A1} yesterday remains in force and applies to all
of your evidence.  Do you understand?
WITNESS:  Yes, sir.
PRESIDENT:  Mr Catchpole.
MR CATCHPOLE:  And before I ask any questions, one very
small matter of housekeeping relating to the
supplemental {A2} agreements 1 to 3, which were disclosed to
the claimants in redacted form.
I sought to understand why the redactions have been
applied and it transpires that, as one would expect, it
has -- the agreements {A3} all have confidentiality clauses
in them and they don't just relate to -- there's other
trade subcontractors referred to.  However, the
confidentiality clauses do contain a provision tt that
say -- that doesn't apply if there's an order of the
tribunal.
So if the tribunal was minded to make an order that
we disclose the unredacted versions of all three
agreements, we have copies of them available.  But it's
a matter I can't make a submission on.
PRESIDENT:  Mr Hickey, do you apply for such an order?
MR HICKEY:  Yes, please.
PRESIDENT:  The order is granted.
MR CATCHPOLE:  Then they will be made available.  Thank you.
Cross-examination by MR CATCHPOLE (continued)
MR CATCHPOLE:  Good morning, Mr Grgurev.  When we broke last
night, we were just looking at your involvement in the
submission and preparation of the EOT claims at the end
of 2020 that went to Omnium, just to orientate
ourselves.  I just want to follow that trail, if we may.
Could we just go to D10284-2, please.
Here we have an email from Omnium, which is sent to
Mr Kumar of Specon, and Mr Kumar was?
A.  Sunil was our accounts, yeah.
Q.  It was copied to you, you're the last copy recipient,
and he is asking, Omnium are asking for further
information, you see the second paragraph:
"We note that we have only received the cost code
summary page which states the cost incurred, the type of
cost and then the description of 'Project Cost'.  This
is not sufficient for the exercise we are undertaking
and we will require the ledger with descriptions,
supplier information, cost incurred and invoice
reference for each item..."
They're asking for further substantiation from
Specon; is that right?
A.  That's correct, yeah.
Q.  The only person who can give that information is Specon?
A.  It's our account office, head office, yes, Mr Sunil,
yeah.
Q.  If one goes up the page, page 1, same document, please,
go up, page 1, you can see that that information is then
being provided for certain samples?
A.  Yes.
Q.  If we could then go forward to D10386 and start at
page 5 on that.
What you can see here, not an email exchange you
were involved in, but if you go to page 5, please,
16th -- keep going down.  That's it, thank you.
This is Omnium liaising with Mr Patze, 16 November,
and what we see is that he is saying to Mr Patze:
"As discussed on the phone, please see below request
for further substantiation required from Specon to
conclude the attached claim ..."
Then he lists a whole load of items that are
required.
Mr Patze is following up on his own to see whether
Omnium have got all the information they need from
Specon; is that right?  Is that looking after your
interests?
A.  Yes, yes.  Yes, counsel.
Q.  If we then please go up slightly on that, you see
Mr Patze is responding, saying -- well, this is in
relation to additional engineering drafting claim:
"Hi Charlie,
In continuation of the Email below, please find also
in attachment the SDIR log ... for SDIRs specifically
related to M2M3 scope ..."
So he's actually proactively providing information
in support of your claim; is that right?
A.  That's correct, counsel.
Q.  Then on -- if you go, please, to D10386-4 -- sorry, that
is what we're on.
If you then go up, please, to right at the top of
the page, email of the 19th -- sorry, go down one, if
you go down a little bit further.  Sorry.  Keep going
down to the email next.  The next email.
So Bernard Patze then emails you directly, says:
"Please see below the mail received from Charlie.
Let's have maximum information available by
Saturday."
You're directly involved in these discussions?
A.  Yes, of course, counsel.  I can see from quickly reading
through the above email from myself, that this is the
part of the design revisions and everything, all this
history and trackers that were mentioned in the previous
mail that you showed.
Q.  Yes, but this is your --
A.  So, yes --
Q.  This is Specon's claim --
A.  Yes, yes, yes.
Q.  -- and you're the one -- he's actually trying to get you
to get the substantiation that Omnium need in order to
make an assessment; is that right?
A.  That's correct.
Q.  Looking after your interests, is he?
A.  Absolutely.
Q.  Could we go up, please.  Then you respond, and you say:
"Please find herewith enclosed complete
substantiation documents requested by Omnium, including
specific impact and quantum of SDWGS that required
redesign, against each and every RFI response received,
as well as FCN Sketches ...
... obvious ... that ... majority ..."
Skip over.  And then to be fair, the last paragraph
on the next page:
"We have tried to provide information within short
time permitted against initial query of Omnium for the
4 elements listed thereto."
And you say:
"This exercise will require substantially more time
to prepare, but we will start working on it."
So is this right, that the sort of substantiation
that was being required, in order to justify your
claims, hadn't yet -- you hadn't actually started the
exercise to compile that; was that right?
A.  Can you repeat your question?
Q.  At this stage, even though you were in advanced
discussions with, effectively, Omnium, trying to
substantiate your claim, the information that you
require, Specon requires, in order to be able to
substantiate it, has not yet started to be prepared?
A.  As you can see here, the email response, the email
addressing to me, I have organised my team and responded
to Bernard, but all the documentation related to the
revision of the design, or all the substantiation that
is gathered for Besix is available on Aconex.
I mean, we all have access to Aconex, but we
recognise this proactive approach of Mr Bernard and
I put, as you can see in my comments, complete
engineering team to gather him as better quality
information as he requested, yeah.
Q.  You're not suggesting, are you, that the JV had
a responsibility to formulate your claim for submission
to the employer?  You had to do that, didn't you?
A.  That's correct, yeah.  We have to do it, yeah.
Q.  Could you then go, please, to D10394-2.
This is an email from you, 6 December 2020:
"Please find herewith attached SPECON's Consolidated
Claims Summary Report, as requested by Omnium during
initial meeting with them in our Head Office.  We will
share it formally with you under cover of letter
tomorrow.  You are kindly requested to forward it to
them BTB, for perusal and consideration."
What does "BTB" mean?
A.  Back-to-back.
Q.  Why are you saying it should be back-to-back?
A.  I mean, comprehensively.
Q.  And also that the valuation and the payment, if any, was
going to come from the employer and then be passed down
to you by the JV?
A.  Correct, yeah.
Q.  There's been meetings; were you at the meetings with
Omnium?
A.  No.
Q.  So far, is there anything wrong with what the JV has
done in handling and pursuing your claims?
A.  No, I mean, many of these emails I was not copied, but
I can see that Mr Bernard Patze acted proactively and we
have responded fairly promptly to their request, as you
can see from this email.
Q.  It's all of this information and that claim which leads
to the Omnium valuation that eventually goes into the
supplemental agreement that you sign with the JV
in June?
A.  Yes, after the supplemental agreement of the JV with the
client, I suppose, yes.
Q.  That's the 48 -- you have a credit for 48.3 million that
comes out of their assessment of all of the claims that
were being submitted through the JV by Specon at this
time?
A.  Again, counsel, the negotiation of our settlement
agreement was done by our COO and CEO.  This sum that
was agreed with your client in June, five months after
their agreement with the client, was negotiated by my
management.  You can see here, they're copied, Stelios
and Mr Thrasos.
Q.  You knew -- and just so we're clear, I'm not saying it's
the engineer's assessment -- you knew that the result of
all these submissions -- so for prolongation costs,
disruption, engineering and wild air, all going in,
Omnium valued them at about a 48.3 million dirhams?
A.  Yeah.  I mean, this information I don't have, counsel.
I mean, what I have is the document that my company
agreed with Besix during negotiations, so exact figure
of Omnium allocated to us, we were never shared that,
that report or any details of it.
Q.  If Omnium -- assume Omnium did value it at around
48.3 million.  Does it follow from that that they did
not find that the vast majority of your claim had been
substantiated?
A.  Can you repeat the question?
Q.  If they valued your claims at about 48.3 million
dirhams, does it follow that they did not accept that
most of your claims had been substantiated by Specon?
A.  I'm not aware to have seen response from or shared
response from Omnium or any evaluation of our claims,
prior to the supplementary agreement.
Q.  As far as I'm aware, no further claims, EOT claims or
claims for disruption or prolongation costs, are
submitted by Specon after the end of 2020 until
termination?
A.  Not sure, counsellor, not sure.  The nature of the
supplementary agreement was specific of what to do to
the end of the project committed to the client.  So
I really don't recall if we have worked on some claims
or something, but --
Q.  You're the project director.  Do you recall ever
submitting further claims for prolongation, EOTs,
disruption, additional engineering costs, wild air, in
the period January 2021 through to November 2021?
A.  I would say that for any late information from design or
variation elements of the works, we would continue to
produce the notices.  Did we submit the claim or update
of the claim?  I really don't remember anything like
that.
Q.  Those submissions we have been looking at also resulted
in an extension of time being granted to Specon.  Do you
recall that?
A.  I repeat, counsel, that the agreement, our supplementary
agreement that was shared with me, is the result of the
lump sum negotiation with the project management of your
client.  We have no detailed information of or written
document from your client saying that we have been
granted extension of time.
Q.  Can we look at D8679-1.
It seems Mr Hickey has a problem.
MR HICKEY:  My transcript is frozen.  You carry on.
MR CATCHPOLE:  Do you see here we have a letter,
31 March 2021, addressed to you as project director?  Do
you see that?
A.  Yes.
Q.  Do you see what the heading says?  It says,
"... Re: Extension of Time"; do you see that?
It says:
"The Contractor has been carrying out discussions
and negotiations with the Employer in order to secure an
extension to the Project's Time For Completion and an
agreement on how and when the Project is to be completed
by.  When these discussions commenced, the Contractor
made the Subcontractor aware of them and what their
intended purpose was."
That was right, isn't it?  You knew about those?
A.  Yes.
Q.  "The Contractor hereby records that they have entered
into a Supplementary Agreement with the Employer.  In
accordance with our obligation under Sub-Clause 14.3 of
the Conditions of Subcontract, we hereby notify you that
as a part of the aforementioned Supplementary Agreement,
the Employer has revised the Project's Time For
Completion from 30th April 2019 to 10th December 2019."
That would be the date for completion in the rev 7
programme.  Do you recall that?
A.  This, counsel, if you don't mind, this date adjustment
was there for three, four years.  The main contract
completion date was April 2019, where we, one year later
in 2017, when we were awarded the contract, our
completion date was 30 August 2019.
So this movement from 30 April to the revised date
of the revision 7, you're correct, to December.  It's,
in my opinion, informing us of both, adjusting their
original gap against our completion date --
Q.  -- (overspeaking) -- can we look at what the facts are:
"As a consequence of this, the Subcontractor's Time
For Completion has also been revised to
10 December 2019."
Do you see that?
A.  Yes, yes, I --
Q.  That is a formal grant of an extension of time to Specon
to 10 December 2019; is that right?  (Pause)
Is that right?
A.  I would say that this is the completion date of the
programme 7 that we have not formally accepted.
Q.  Is that a formal extension of time to the
subcontractor's time for completion under the
subcontract?
A.  This is revised completion date under the programme 7,
in my opinion, by --
Q.  Is this a formal extension of time to the
subcontractor's time for completion under the
subcontract?
A.  We could consider this as extension of time up
to December 2019 if the revision 7 programme was issued
formally to us as a revised contractor baseline
programme.  But --
Q.  Was this a formal extension of time to the
subcontractor's time for completion under the
subcontract?
A.  It is revised time for completion of the project date,
yes.
Q.  Thank you.  It's not very difficult, is it?
So why did you say a moment ago that you did not get
an extension of time?
A.  Because in my opinion, we have lost our right for
a proper extension of time claim because the main
contractor opted to issue the revision 7 programme with
this completion date for monitoring purpose only,
therefore as a target programme, not as a revised
contractor's programme.
Q.  What has that got to do with anything, Mr Grgurev?  This
is the consequence of, amongst other things, putting
forward your claims for extensions of time, along with
JV's, other trade contractors' as well?
A.  It is my opinion, counsel.  You know, it's my opinion
from experience before in a similar case, yeah.
Q.  Would it be possible that your opinion is actually
seeking to argue a position that you would like to argue
on behalf of Specon, rather than actually what happened?
A.  That's not my intention.
Q.  Do you have an interest, financial interest in the
outcome of this case, as a matter of interest?
A.  Absolutely not, counsel.
Q.  Can we please come back to your general criticism of the
JV, which you have in your first witness statement at
3.3(b) and we have it at B9-13.
This was the paragraph we looked at before.
A.  Yes.
Q.  The second general criticism which we will look at is
the "SBJV's failure to provide an updated Main
Contractor programme".
I know this is subject to an errata from you, which
we will look at, but I just want to skim over what you
said in your witness statement, please, and what the
criticism is.
If we could go to paragraph 4.6, if we start here,
this is under the heading about -- a general heading
about programmes, and I'm going to skim over them, but
just to refresh your memory of what you said, you said
"Not having an updated subcontract programme also
caused complications with managing the Subcontract Works
internally."
Does it follow from that that, whatever the reason
was, you felt at the time that you had problems managing
the subcontract works internally?
A.  Yes, counsel.  What is your question?
Q.  Does it follow from what you've just said, whatever the
cause, that you felt, at the time, that you had
complications with managing the subcontract works
internally?
A.  As this paragraph 4.6(a) clearly shows, this is the
communication of my -- as an example -- of my test and
commissioning manager.  It relates to the access granted
to our works and readiness of combine all other
services, for example, the rooms.  Regardless of our
readiness, we depend on the closing of the door, closing
of the other activities of other contractors.
Q.  All I'm asking is a simple question.
A.  Yes, please.
Q.  First sentence, you say the fact that you did not have
an updated subcontract programme "caused complications
with managing the Subcontract Works internally".  Do you
see that?
A.  Yes.
Q.  Does it follow from that that, whatever the cause, your
view, at the time, was that you were having
complications with managing the subcontract works
internally?
A.  I didn't mention the word "complication".  I just
mention I had to manage the issues internally, as I can
see here.
Q.  Shall we read it again, Mr Grgurev?
A.  Yes, please.
Q.  "Not having an updated subcontract programme also caused
complications..."
Is that your word or did someone else put it in
there?
A.  "... complications with managing the Subcontract Works
internally", counsel, means we had constraints, we had
lack of information of the preceding activities, because
we were never shared the monthly updates of the
programme from contractor in five years.  So we had to
organise, in the way, to follow; wherever the work we
observed was ready by other contractors, we would then
plan our day-to-day activities.
Q.  Does it follow that at the time, you are saying that
there were complications with you managing the works
internally at Specon?
A.  I'm trying to say in this statement, in this sentence,
that it also caused complications to us to manage the
subcontractor works internally.
Q.  All I'm asking you: does it follow, as a matter of fact,
that it caused complications, so you actually had
complications with managing the subcontract works
internally?
A.  We were caused complications, counsel.
Q.  So the answer is yes, it did?  You had complications
with managing?
A.  Yes, yes, of course, which is elaborating on --
Q.  It's not very difficult, is it?  It's "yes" or "no";
that does help sometimes.
Paragraph 4.7:
"However, as explained ... despite our requests,
SBJV failed to provide any updated Main Contract
Programmes ... This greatly impacted Specon, as we could
not accurately update our own Subcontract Programme, as
we did not have knowledge of the progress or status of
the predecessor works."
A.  That's correct.
Q.  4.8, you say:
"... it is highly relevant for the MEP Subcontractor
to have [it] so that it can coordinate, integrate, and
plan its activities."
Then it says there's lots of dependencies.
4.9, you then deal with the revised programmes, it
says:
"Over the course of the Project, SBJV issued
'Contractor Revised Programmes'.  These 'Contractor
Revised Programmes' were issued as follows."
The first one is:
"on 9 January 2018, SBJV issued via Aconex
transmittal the Rev 07 Programme..."
So that's -- you identify that that, as far as
you're concerned, is the formal issue of the rev 7
baseline programme; is that right?
A.  This is not rev 7 baseline programme, because your
client opted to call it monitoring purpose only
programme, which define it as target programme.
Q.  Why did you call it the rev 7 baseline programme?
A.  This is in brackets, counsel.
Q.  I know it is, but they're your words, so why did you
call it that?
A.  With brackets, in the entire context of this section 4,
you can elaborate my statement and details of my
statement.  We have never received a revised baseline
programme from the main contractor, neither as
revision 7, neither as revision 8, despite it was
approved by the client to issue it to all
subcontractors, revision 8 as a baseline programme.
Q.  Did you understand that what was issued to you on
9 January 2018 was part of the rev 7 -- finalised rev 7
programme that was being issued, for whatever purpose,
by the JV?
A.  It is acknowledged as such and I think that I have
acknowledged it as such, to the extent of its
definition.  They call it monitoring purpose only.
Q.  Right, and you say, to be fair to you, in 4.10, that:
"These 'Contractor Revised Programmes' showed the
MEP activities in complete isolation."
And didn't include any other activities.
Then in 4.11, you say:
"Even when producing these updated revisions, SBJV
would issue the 'programme' for 'use to monitor and
record the progress of the Works'.  These 'updates' were
prepared in isolation and did not include any
predecessor activities and simply appeared to set out
the duration of the M2 and M3 Works."
Yes?
A.  Yeah, that initial file, yes, that's correct.
Q.  Then please can you go forward to paragraph 4.14.
You say:
"... 9 January ... Aconex transmittal, SBJV issued
the Rev 07 Baseline Programme."
Told you what you had to do with it.
Then 15, you said:
"I did not, nor do I have any knowledge that anyone
else at Specon, had any input in the discussions, or
decisions which led to the finalised Rev 07 Baseline
Programme."
So that's presumably the finalised rev 7 on
9 January; is that right?
A.  Yes, yes.  I mean, this point 4.14 is clearly a request
from your client for us to produce loading of the
programme.  They have shared at that time basically MEP,
MEP file, and ask us to incorporate the resource load,
the quantities and the cost load, yeah, as we did
similarly in rev 7, yes.
Q.  4.17, you say you wrote asking for further information
and said you would produce your own programme once it
was formally issued.
4.18, you say you write on the same day requesting
additional information, because you needed it to prepare
your programme.
Then on 4.19, you say we did not get a response, so
wrote another letter on 5 March.
Then 4.20, which is the one that is the subject of
an errata, you say:
"I do not recall receiving any response from the
SBJV to the above letters and SBJV did not provide the
master Rev 07 programme, or the additional information
requested."
You say you continued to raise this at various
meetings.  That has now been revised, if you want to see
it, to B9A-2, please.  Two amendments.  The first one --
the other one relates to the rev 8 programme:
"I do not recall specifying any response from
SBJV ..."
Then you had asserted that we didn't provide the
full master programme, but it's been brought to your
attention:
"... that SBJV issued the Rev 07 Baseline Programme
to Specon by way of letter dated 15 April ... However,
this programme was issued 'to monitor and record
progress' only."
So does it follow from that that at the time, you
were unaware -- is this your evidence -- that you had
actually been issued the full rev 7 programme showing
all stakeholders' interests?
A.  Yeah, I mean, as you can see, the trail, it end up end
of March and actually three weeks later, yes, it came to
my knowledge.  I mean, this was years back, you know --
Q.  So, to be clear, to your knowledge, you do not recall
ever seeing or receiving the full rev 7 programme?
A.  Comprehensive, yes.  I mean, this is obviously fact.
Q.  Can we look at that, please.  D340.  This is the
transmittal to which you refer.  Indeed, it does show,
if we go down a little bit, under message, that you are
required to action the items mentioned below, resource
load the programme with manpower, resource load the
programme with quantities and generate KPIs.
Why would you be required to generate KPIs?
A.  We have used -- I mean, your client has used the KPIs
basically to run the project.
Q.  So what's the purpose of the KPIs?
A.  KPIs is to establish the planning -- short-term planning
or the task of different contractors and assign the
specific task to be achieved on short term.
Q.  Is this right, that Specon are being asked to produce
their KPIs in order to meet their obligations in
accordance with this programme?
A.  KPIs, yes.  Yes, as a part of the planning, yes.  KPIs
are led by the multiple contractors' involvement, so you
have to -- for short-term planning, you use the KPIs
from all the subcontractors together.
MR STEWART:  Mr Catchpole, just so I understand, this is
9 January.
MR CATCHPOLE:  Yes.
MR STEWART:  Is this the one -- is this the full version?
MR CATCHPOLE:  No.
MR STEWART:  Right.
MR CATCHPOLE:  Were you aware that this was actually a work
in progress?  It wasn't an issue of -- it was being
developed at the time and Specon's input was being
sought into the development of rev 7 programme?  Do you
recall that?
A.  Not prior to 9 January.
Q.  Do you recall that 9 January, it was not an issue of the
final version or an extract of it; it was a work in
progress where the JV was trying to get Specon to input
into and develop a programme which would eventually
become rev 7?
A.  But this is, counsel, the part of my confusion.
I recall that initially, we received only in isolation
the MEP activities, with the same request: produce the
loading, produce this.  You can see the trail of the
correspondence going all the way for three months up to
the end of March.  Yes, and then eventually, on Aconex,
we received the full programme, yeah.
Q.  Do you recall that when this is issued, it was
a tentative programme in January 2018, but what was
going on was that the JV was wanting Specon to get
involved in developing the rev 7 programme?
A.  Again, counsel, once you share to each subcontractor his
activities in isolation, this is not participation in
developing the programme.  This is to fill up your part
for the fraction of the programme that your client
wanted to put together then as a complete programme.
Q.  Is it your evidence that you did not understand that
what was going on at this time was that the programme
would be developed in collaboration with all of the
subcontractors, including Specon?
A.  What I recall is we have never been invited to any
workshop leading to 9 January.  Since 9 January, my
planning team might have participated in some of the
workshops leading to the full disclosure in April that
you showed me.
Q.  Did they or didn't they, to your recollection?
A.  I cannot remember.
Q.  D498-7, please.
Can we go down to page 7, please.
D498-7.  It's the wrong reference.
Who was Sheik Sarhan?
A.  This is our planning manager at the time, yeah.
Q.  Can you go down, can you go to the bottom email, up
a bit, up a bit, please.  Thank you, on page 7.
That's it.
So here we have Mr Sarhan sending an email to you on
14 February, and he is actually looking at tentative
manpower histogram, as per rev 7.  Do you see that?
A.  Yes, yes.
Q.  He's working on how to resource and plan Specon's works
in accordance with a tentative programme; is that right?
A.  He's done the extract of the comprehensive programme
rev 7 for MEP activities only.  So we have collaborated.
That's why I'm trying to say I have -- that's why
I mention earlier, I was not 100 per cent sure, but we
were cooperative, even though we were shared extract of
MEP activities in isolation.  So we can still do the
loading, we can still make a calculation of labour, but
that doesn't constitute knowledge or involvement in
overall programme creation, yeah.
Q.  Could we just go up a little bit further on page 7.  So
Mr Markou is getting involved and he's saying: that
doesn't work, the mobilisation is too steep, have you
checked you have sufficient materials?  There's a big
jump in May.  So he's got a whole load of thing about
the sequencing, planning, how it's going to work; is
that right?
A.  Yes, that's our general manager, Costas, yes.  He's
giving some comments on that work prepared by planner,
yeah.
Q.  Then on page 2 of the same -- go down a little bit.
That's it.
Mr Thrasyvoulou comes in, same day, saying: that's
not what the charts suggest, they suggest an extra
6 million AED from previously calculated for men, based
on your planning.  Do you see that?
A.  He's comparing it, I believe, to baseline 6 and
allowance in the budget for the manpower, yeah.
Q.  Then if we could go up to the bottom of page 1, you come
back and say, dealing with concerns of senior
management, that you'll "... review it with Sarhan and
revert back to you".  Do you see that?
A.  Yes, I will cross-check works of my planner, yes, yes.
Q.  If we look at the top of page 1, that's exactly what
happens: Mr Sarhan goes and sends back comparisons.
Can you go to D19, please.
Top of the page, please.  Sorry, no, go down, that's
right.  See at 14 February -- do you know who Mr Nelson
Telan is?
A.  One of the planners from your client, yeah, I believe.
MR STEWART:  Is this date right?  2017?
MR CATCHPOLE:  Actually, that can't be right.
A.  It's actually not right, yeah.
Q.  That can't be right.  Just go up a moment, just go up to
